subject:
Re: [cc-community] Strayform - where artists and fans connecttofund
	and distribute new creative works
body:
Hi, 
Paying for the bands expenses is like giving an
incubation. Its a one time thing (or two time) until the band begins to
make ends meet, but only if it is done by a firm/company, the whole
stock market thing, doesnt appeal to me as much. The company can do all
the management work for the band, get concerts, design merchandise,
sell stuff etc. Profit sharing being the underlying business model.
Like Drew said, the fans are in any way paying thro CDs and downloads,
concerts, Ts etc. 

BY-SA allows remixing so that people can work over your music to create
their own and still use it for commercial purposes. But for that they
will need a platform for distribution and if you are one, you should be
happy about it. So for me BY-SA is the best choice for digi music. 

A social networking site can connect the fans to artists and it
can do more than that. It can connect music enthusiasts with artists.
It can bring forth a community of music reviewers, people who will
explore music and in effect get more stuff for your venture. 
Well thats a thing I hope. 

Cheers,

Ujjwal

> >> > I've looked into several possibilities here in the UK.  There's a number
of> > projects which gain government funding for "charitable work", or"community> > work" which benefits others at reduced or no cost.  We have a community> > studio locally for instance, I could record stuff there cheaply, or
> > continue to do as I do now and record stuff in my own home setup.  I'mnot> > sure if a band could run as a registered charity, though it's an> > interesting concept ;)>
> That is an idea. Pay expenses of band, including band members, roadies,etc.> salaries. Release the music under a Free (and in my book, copyleft)license.> This is certainly a benefit to the public.
Yes.  The only drawback I can see is that it's no longer "charitable" whenthey are fed back into the commercial ticketing system, you'd have to createsome kind of not-for-profit deriv.  Renders the whole thing a bit of a
non-starter.  Though having said that they could do "free" concerts andbring along the t-shirts and the merch......who knows.

Crimea> > point out.>> The thing is, if the music came with a Free license and I liked, I would> happily pay the band for a CD. (Actually, I have been thinking recentlythat> it might be a nice twist to go back to the "album format" for delivery of
> CDs. Basically, album size, materials, posters, lyrics, etc. with a CDinside> instead of vinyl. Is it clear what I mean here?)Yes.  That's exactly the kind of thing I'd love to see, and I agree, I'd
happily pay good money for something like that.  I think one of the issueswith CDs is that the price remained fixed whilst the "costs" bottomed out.Most music lovers and consumers are well aware of the costs now, especially
as daily newspapers include "free" CDs and DVDs whilst still paying dues tothe artists and creators.  It's difficult to convince people to pay for dataI guess.So it's the additional and exclusive things people expect to pay more for,
the physical things they can touch, wear or play with.  I kept my old vinylbecause some of the artwork is simply iconic, awesome stuff from the 70s and80s.  I was thinking of framing some of those old album covers.
It'd be great to bring back that sense of ownership, the internet is a greatplace for things like fanclubs and fan-feedback, though we're not seeing somuch of that just yet - beyond myspace..
